title: How to Make Dumpling Wrappers

methods.name: Making Dumpling Dough with a Stand Mixer

steps.headline: Pour your flour and salt together in the bowl of a stand mixer.
steps.description: Place 3 and 3/8 cups (420 g) of all-purpose flour and 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of salt in the bowl of your mixer. Use your dough hook attachment to mix the flour and salt on low speed for 10 seconds.

steps.headline: Add your water.
steps.description: With the mixer running on low, pour 7/8 cups (210 ml) of lukewarm tap water into the mixing bowl. When the mixer fully incorporates the water into the dough and there is no more flour showing, increase the mixer speed to medium. Using hot water will yield dumplings with a thinner skin. This might be desirable if you are frying your dumplings, but it may make the dumplings fall apart if you plan to boil them. Adjust your water temperature for your desired dumpling cooking method and skill level. (Thinner skins may tear more easily when wrapping, too.)

steps.headline: Knead your dough for 6-8 minutes.
steps.description: With the mixer on medium, knead the dough until it is a smooth, single mass. The dough will begin to coalesce on the dough hook in the middle of the bowl. This will take approximately 6-8 minutes.

steps.headline: Scrape the dough out of the mixer.
steps.description: Use a floured hand or a dough scraper to remove the dumpling dough from the mixer. Place it on a floured work surface, so the dough doesn’t stick.

steps.headline: Form the dough into a ball.
steps.description: Using your hands, shape the dough into a round ball. If the dough sticks to your hands, dust them with a little extra flour so you can work with the dough easily. If the dough is crumbly and not holding together, add a spoonful of water at a time, incorporating with your hands, until it is one mass. Always try to be conservative when adjusting with water. Less is more!

steps.headline: Cover the dough, and let it rest for 15 minutes.. Cover the dough with a clean kitchen towel that’s not terry cloth.
steps.description: Set a timer for 15 minutes, and let the dough rest on your work surface.

steps.headline: Knead your dough for 2-3 minutes, and let it rest again.
steps.description: When your timer goes off, flour your hands and knead the dough for 2-3 minutes. When the dough begins to stiffen again and provide some resistance as you knead, set it aside to rest for at least 1 hour. Resting your dough for much longer than 1 hour yields a softer dough that is easier to work with, but the wrappers may be less elastic. This may make them more prone to tearing when you try to fill them. Depending upon your skill level, you can decide how long your wrappers should rest. If you’re just starting out, try resting your dough for 1 hour. You can adjust as you see fit next time. After the rest time is complete, your dough is ready to be shaped into wrappers.

steps.headline: Combine 3 and 3/8 cups (420 g) of flour and 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of salt.
steps.description: Place a large kitchen bowl on top of a towel to keep it from slipping while you work. Add your flour and salt, stirring with a spoon to incorporate the 2 ingredients.

steps.headline: Form a small well in the flour and salt.
steps.description: Use your hands to create a sunken area in the middle of your dry ingredients by moving some of the flour mix to the sides of the bowl. You will have a little “bowl” within your bowl to pour your water.

steps.headline: Add 7/8 cups (210 ml) of water to the bowl.
steps.description: Stir your dry ingredients with a wooden spoon as you pour your water into the well you created in a steady stream. Aim to evenly moisten the dry ingredients, pushing flour-ier bits toward the middle where there is more moisture. It’s okay if there are lots of lumpy bits even when you’ve added all your water.

steps.headline: Knead your dough in the bowl.
steps.description: Use your hands to knead the dough into a single mass in the kitchen bowl. If your dough doesn’t come together easily, add a spoonful of water at a time, kneading until it comes together into a single ball. Turn your mass of dough out onto a floured work surface.

steps.headline: Knead your dough by hand for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Use the heels of your palms to knead your dough, working it until it becomes elastic and smooth. The dough is ready when it bounces back slightly if you poke it. (A small, lasting finger impression is okay.) This should take about 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Place your dough in a plastic bag and rest it for up to 2 hours.
steps.description: Place your dough into a zip-top bag, squeezing out any excess air before sealing. Rest the dough in the bag for at least 15 minutes but not longer than 2 hours. The dough will steam up the bag as it rests. That’s okay! Once rested, your dough is ready to be shaped into wrappers.

steps.headline: Shape your dough into a fat circle.
steps.description: Turn your dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. With your hands, reshape your dough into a ball if necessary. Push a thumb through the center of the dough to form a thick circle. Dust the center of the hole with flour to keep it from sticking together.

steps.headline: Make the hole in your dough larger.
steps.description: Use your hands to pull the dough apart gently into a larger circle, gradually enlarging the hole in the middle of the dough. As you do this, the outer ring of dough will become thinner. Keep going until your ring of dough is about 3 centimetres (1.2 in) in diameter.

steps.headline: Cut your circle of dough in half to form two logs.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to slice your dough circle into two equal “C” shaped halves. Straighten each half on your work surface so you have two long logs of dough.

steps.headline: Use a sharp knife to slice the dough into portions for your wrappers.
steps.description: Slice each log of dough into rounds of about 10 grams (0.35 oz) each. A kitchen scale can be useful to see about how large each piece should be, but it doesn’t need to be perfect. Divide all your dough this way until the logs are completely divided. Dust the pieces with flour so they don’t stick together. If you don’t have a scale, aim to make each piece about as wide as the log is thick—about 3 centimetres (1.2 in). If the rounds become a bit pinched as you cut, that’s not a problem. Each of these individual pieces will form a dumpling wrapper.

steps.headline: Shape each piece into a small disk with your hands.
steps.description: Flatten a piece of the cut dough with your palm to make a crude circle. Using your fingers, press the dough into a more round circle shape, evening out any areas of uneven thickness. You’ll use a rolling pin to get the perfect size.

steps.headline: Use a rolling pin to thin out the edges of your dumpling wrapper.
steps.description: Flour a rolling pin, and use it to roll your rough circle into a circle of approximately 8 centimetres (3.1 in) to 10 centimetres (3.9 in) in diameter. Rather than rolling your dumpling from one edge across to the other, roll from the center out towards the edge, rotating the wrapper by quarter turns for evenness as you go. This rolling technique will create dumpling wrappers that are thinner at the edges and slightly thicker in the middle to hold your filling!

steps.headline: Do 3-5 wrappers at a time then wrap them up tightly in plastic wrap.
steps.description: Keep your dumpling wrappers from drying out by wrapping your finished wrappers up in small batches as you work. Dust the rounds if necessary to keep them from sticking to each other in a stack. If possible, ask a friend to fill the dumplings as you finish making each of the wrappers. Repeat the flattening, rolling and wrapping process until you’ve finished creating all your dumpling wrappers. That’s it! Fill your dumpling wrappers and cook them as you wish.

text: Making Dumpling Dough with a Stand Mixer Pour your flour and salt together in the bowl of a stand mixer. Place 3 and 3/8 cups (420 g) of all-purpose flour and 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of salt in the bowl of your mixer. Use your dough hook attachment to mix the flour and salt on low speed for 10 seconds. Add your water. With the mixer running on low, pour 7/8 cups (210 ml) of lukewarm tap water into the mixing bowl. When the mixer fully incorporates the water into the dough and there is no more flour showing, increase the mixer speed to medium. Using hot water will yield dumplings with a thinner skin. This might be desirable if you are frying your dumplings, but it may make the dumplings fall apart if you plan to boil them. Adjust your water temperature for your desired dumpling cooking method and skill level. (Thinner skins may tear more easily when wrapping, too.) Knead your dough for 6-8 minutes. With the mixer on medium, knead the dough until it is a smooth, single mass. The dough will begin to coalesce on the dough hook in the middle of the bowl. This will take approximately 6-8 minutes. Scrape the dough out of the mixer. Use a floured hand or a dough scraper to remove the dumpling dough from the mixer. Place it on a floured work surface, so the dough doesn’t stick. Form the dough into a ball. Using your hands, shape the dough into a round ball. If the dough sticks to your hands, dust them with a little extra flour so you can work with the dough easily. If the dough is crumbly and not holding together, add a spoonful of water at a time, incorporating with your hands, until it is one mass. Always try to be conservative when adjusting with water. Less is more! Cover the dough, and let it rest for 15 minutes.. Cover the dough with a clean kitchen towel that’s not terry cloth. Set a timer for 15 minutes, and let the dough rest on your work surface. Knead your dough for 2-3 minutes, and let it rest again. When your timer goes off, flour your hands and knead the dough for 2-3 minutes. When the dough begins to stiffen again and provide some resistance as you knead, set it aside to rest for at least 1 hour. Resting your dough for much longer than 1 hour yields a softer dough that is easier to work with, but the wrappers may be less elastic. This may make them more prone to tearing when you try to fill them. Depending upon your skill level, you can decide how long your wrappers should rest. If you’re just starting out, try resting your dough for 1 hour. You can adjust as you see fit next time. After the rest time is complete, your dough is ready to be shaped into wrappers. Making Dumpling Dough by Hand Combine 3 and 3/8 cups (420 g) of flour and 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of salt. Place a large kitchen bowl on top of a towel to keep it from slipping while you work. Add your flour and salt, stirring with a spoon to incorporate the 2 ingredients. Form a small well in the flour and salt. Use your hands to create a sunken area in the middle of your dry ingredients by moving some of the flour mix to the sides of the bowl. You will have a little “bowl” within your bowl to pour your water. Add 7/8 cups (210 ml) of water to the bowl. Stir your dry ingredients with a wooden spoon as you pour your water into the well you created in a steady stream. Aim to evenly moisten the dry ingredients, pushing flour-ier bits toward the middle where there is more moisture. It’s okay if there are lots of lumpy bits even when you’ve added all your water. Knead your dough in the bowl. Use your hands to knead the dough into a single mass in the kitchen bowl. If your dough doesn’t come together easily, add a spoonful of water at a time, kneading until it comes together into a single ball. Turn your mass of dough out onto a floured work surface. Knead your dough by hand for 2 minutes. Use the heels of your palms to knead your dough, working it until it becomes elastic and smooth. The dough is ready when it bounces back slightly if you poke it. (A small, lasting finger impression is okay.) This should take about 2 minutes. Place your dough in a plastic bag and rest it for up to 2 hours. Place your dough into a zip-top bag, squeezing out any excess air before sealing. Rest the dough in the bag for at least 15 minutes but not longer than 2 hours. The dough will steam up the bag as it rests. That’s okay! Once rested, your dough is ready to be shaped into wrappers. Shaping Dumpling Wrappers Shape your dough into a fat circle. Turn your dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. With your hands, reshape your dough into a ball if necessary. Push a thumb through the center of the dough to form a thick circle. Dust the center of the hole with flour to keep it from sticking together. Make the hole in your dough larger. Use your hands to pull the dough apart gently into a larger circle, gradually enlarging the hole in the middle of the dough. As you do this, the outer ring of dough will become thinner. Keep going until your ring of dough is about 3 centimetres (1.2 in) in diameter. Cut your circle of dough in half to form two logs. Use a sharp knife to slice your dough circle into two equal “C” shaped halves. Straighten each half on your work surface so you have two long logs of dough. Use a sharp knife to slice the dough into portions for your wrappers. Slice each log of dough into rounds of about 10 grams (0.35 oz) each. A kitchen scale can be useful to see about how large each piece should be, but it doesn’t need to be perfect. Divide all your dough this way until the logs are completely divided. Dust the pieces with flour so they don’t stick together. If you don’t have a scale, aim to make each piece about as wide as the log is thick—about 3 centimetres (1.2 in). If the rounds become a bit pinched as you cut, that’s not a problem. Each of these individual pieces will form a dumpling wrapper. Shape each piece into a small disk with your hands. Flatten a piece of the cut dough with your palm to make a crude circle. Using your fingers, press the dough into a more round circle shape, evening out any areas of uneven thickness. You’ll use a rolling pin to get the perfect size. Use a rolling pin to thin out the edges of your dumpling wrapper. Flour a rolling pin, and use it to roll your rough circle into a circle of approximately 8 centimetres (3.1 in) to 10 centimetres (3.9 in) in diameter. Rather than rolling your dumpling from one edge across to the other, roll from the center out towards the edge, rotating the wrapper by quarter turns for evenness as you go. This rolling technique will create dumpling wrappers that are thinner at the edges and slightly thicker in the middle to hold your filling! Do 3-5 wrappers at a time then wrap them up tightly in plastic wrap. Keep your dumpling wrappers from drying out by wrapping your finished wrappers up in small batches as you work. Dust the rounds if necessary to keep them from sticking to each other in a stack. If possible, ask a friend to fill the dumplings as you finish making each of the wrappers. Repeat the flattening, rolling and wrapping process until you’ve finished creating all your dumpling wrappers. That’s it! Fill your dumpling wrappers and cook them as you wish.
